comments:
This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It also includes other special topics in chemistry.

Some students found that the course was not very math oriented. It was more theoretical, so students had to memorize a lot in order to pass the exams.

Students found that, overall, Professor Topp was able to communicate the material well and was readily available to his students. However, sometimes he rushed through the course material. Professor Topp responds to emails very quickly. Sometimes he is very humorous in class, which reduces some of the boredom. He is very organized and his lecture notes and old exams are helpful in preparing students for current exams. Professor Topp is an excellent instructor. He took the time to explain concepts to students in his office hours and was always very approachable and helpful.

This course fulfills the Physical World Sector. The prerequisite for this course is CHEM 101. Students said the exams were difficult but fair.

Continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.

Students found the course material challenging.

Students found Professor Schelter to be an excellent instructor who was able to effectively convey the ideas through explanations and example problems. He has “a great personality to interact with students but was sometimes inconsistent and difficult to follow in class.” He had great enthusiasm.

Students wished they had a better idea of where their grade stood before the final exam. They found the posted study guides helpful. They expressed that the exams were long and difficult.

This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.

Many students agreed that this was a “very challenging course,” which required “consistent work, class attendance, good time management, and critical thinking skills.” Some students felt the tests were “tricky/difficult” and often “curved on a harsh scale.” However, many students also agreed that they learned a lot from the course. Some students felt that “coverage in lectures was often monotonous, lacking structure or interest.”

Some students found Professor Pietrovito’s lecturing skills to be slightly lacking, citing his “tendency to ramble.” However, students appreciated his “useful lecture notes” and his helpfulness “during office hours and review sessions.” Overall, students found Professor Pietrovito to be “very knowledgeable” about the material.

Completion of homework assignments was not mandatory for the course, and “somewhat tedious at times,” although some felt completion of the homework was necessary to be successful in the class. The course has three midterms, which were found to be “quite difficult” and “considerable studying was necessary” to perform well. The course notes were posted online “in a timely manner, offering students a chance to go through and understand the material.” This course fulfills the Physical World Sector, and has a prerequisite of CHEM101.

This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.

Many students agreed that this was a “very challenging course,” which required “consistent work, class attendance, good time management, and critical thinking skills.” Some students felt the tests were “tricky/difficult” and often “curved on a harsh scale.” However, many students also agreed that they learned a lot from the course. Some students felt that “coverage in lectures was often monotonous, lacking structure or interest.”

Students had mixed reviews about Professor Composto. Some students found that Professor Composto “did a very good job of explaining the material in an understandable way.” Students found that his incorporation of “variety of teaching methods engaged the audience.” Other students felt Professor Composto had some difficulty communicating during the lecture.

Completion of homework assignments was not mandatory for the course, and “somewhat tedious at times,” although some felt completion of the homework was necessary to be successful in the class.
